title: 112_hr2463
content: The "Border Security Technology Innovation Act of 2011" authorizes appropriations under the Homeland Security Act of 2002 for research activities of the Department of Homeland Security. The Under Secretary for Science and Technology of the Department of Homeland Security must ensure that any interagency or intra-agency agreement for developing new technology includes manpower needs, training requirements, and operations costs. The Homeland Security Science and Technology Advisory Committee is reauthorized until December 31, 2014. Additionally, a report on basic research needs for border and maritime security is required. The Comptroller General will assess basic research needs for border and maritime security, including technologies for cargo and people detection, personal protective equipment, document security, advanced screening at ports of entry, and real-time tactical scene awareness. A report on this assessment is due to the House Committee on Science, Space, and Technology and the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation within 6 months of the Act's enactment. Incorporating unmanned aerial vehicles into border/maritime airspace. The Secretary of Homeland Security and the Director of the Joint Planning and Development Office are researching and developing technologies for unmanned aerial vehicles to operate in national airspace for border and maritime security missions. Pilot projects will be conducted in designated test ranges to accelerate the safe integration of unmanned aircraft. The Joint Planning and Development Office is conducting research to integrate unmanned aircraft systems into the national airspace system for various missions. SEC. 7. RESEARCH PROGRAM IN TUNNEL DETECTION. The Under Secretary will research technologies for detecting tunnels, focusing on real-time capabilities. Coordination with other federal agencies is required. SEC. 8. RESEARCH IN ANTICOUNTERFEIT TECHNOLOGIES. The Under Secretary, in coordination with the National Institute of Standards and Technology, will continue a joint research program on anticounterfeit technologies and standards. This includes developing counterfeit-resistant documentation, devices, validation technologies, and identification standards. Consultation with other federal agencies like Immigration and Customs Enforcement, State, Defense, and Justice is required. A report to Congress is due within 12 months of enactment. The Under Secretary and the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology will provide a report to Congress detailing the actions taken under this Act. SEC. 9. STUDY OF MOBILE BIOMETRIC TECHNOLOGIES AT THE BORDER. The Under Secretary, in coordination with the Commissioner of United States Customs and Border Protection, will research the use of mobile biometric technology at the Nation's borders between ports of entry. This includes analyzing existing technologies, examining end-user requirements, and developing recommendations to address capability gaps. The Under Secretary will research gaps in mobile biometric technologies and explore the feasibility of a pilot program at the border. Consultation with relevant agencies and law enforcement officials will be conducted, and coordination with existing biometric programs within the Department of Homeland Security will be ensured. A report on the research findings must be submitted to Congress within 12 months of the enactment of this Act.
